column33: audio books (download them from the library!) are a great resource. For older children who can play
column36: set up times for them to do this. Then establish your expectations so that your kids know you mean business. You deserve safe breaks and quiet moments to be on your own
column37: as do they. ? 5. Exercise and go outside If possible
column38: help everyone continue exercising. Got a dog? Walk it! (While still practising social distancing.) Feeling anxious? Do yoga
column40: meditation?or whatever works for your household. Got a dog? Walk (or run) it
column41: suggests Joanne Seiff. (Soloviova Liudmyla/Shutterstock) Got a yard? Bring your kids out to play in it.? And if the weather's bad
column42: turn on dance music (I recommend the cable music channels
column43: switching at random!) and have a dance party in the living room. 6. Have fun It may sound crazy
column44: but a long stretch of enforced routine means that every treat or change is more enjoyable for everyone involved. This might be the time to make creative desserts
column45: face time on the computer with relatives
column46: play board games or pursue favourite hobbies. Schedule movie nights
column47: play jacks?or tell each other stories. 7. Practise gratitude While we struggle through this
column48: we can count our blessings. Most of us have access to internet

His post included four photographs of himself at the airport looking dutifully concerned. column12: Kenney took along a photographer. But the pictures helped draw attention to his social media post. His post was in no way partisan. The following day the federal government upped its screening process and Kenney thanked the prime minister. Think back to the Fort McMurray fire in 2016 and how then-premier Rachel Notley held daily briefings to update Albertans. Premier Rachel Notley speaks to reporters about the Fort McMurray re-entry plan in May 2016.  (CBC) She seemed to be everywhere. Notley became the face of disaster response. She was rightfully praised. I'm not sure anybody accused her of pandering to the cameras or playing politics. She was simply showing leadership. ""It's about showing people the premier is engaged; people need to see their leader is out there.""? That quote could have come from Notley's communications people in 2016. column14: on Tuesday. Alberta has seen what happens when a premier is not engaged during an emergency.  In 1987

column18: that they won't extinguish one flame or cure one patient. But go off and play golf???and lose your own seat the next election (as Getty did in 1989). This is not to say the Kenney government isn't playing politics. Kenney rushed approval of the provincial budget
column19: limiting debate and making sure his economic plan slid through so quickly he might as well have slathered the walls of the legislative assembly in grease.   Alberta legislature approves $57-billion budget in race against COVID-19 spread   The government made it sound as if the province would grind to a halt during the middle of a pandemic if the budget wasn't passed. column21: the government could have?used supplementary spending to keep the lights on and services intact without having a new budget in effect. The last time that happened was just last year when the NDP government didn't pass a new budget before the provincial election.Things didn't grind to a halt then and they wouldn't have this time.? The NDP understandably accused the government of trying to do an end run around democracy by fast-tracking its budget ??a budget that is already woefully out of date because of the collapse in the price of oil.
